titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: There was a corner of a thunder shower here last Evening, and this morning the thermometers were down as low as 74 and the feeling, cold— At the house Linn Banks moved a Resolution for the adjournment of Congress on the 20th. of this month. days before and after were proposed, and Petrikin who chuses to have every thing in his own way moved the 15th. and the previous question, both of which he carried—the previous question by 113 to 22. and the day, the 15th. by 105 to 95.— This was no sooner announced than Watterson moved a reconsideration—carried 108 to 84. Question again taken on the 15th. rejected 88 to 113. Then the question upon the 21st. was carried without a division— This is a pattern specimen of the consideration and reconsideration of this previous question house— I asked the general consent of the house to present a report from the select Committee on the Memorial from the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia— Cooper of Georgia objected and my Report was not received. But Cooper came afterwards to my seat, and when I explained to him my reason for asking that the report might be received and printed, he said he would not persist in his objection.— The Report from the Secretary of the Treasury of the Commerce and Navigation of the year was received and after some altercation 10,000 extra copies were ordered to be printed.— The Bill from the Senate for continuing the Charters of the District Banks—all of which expire on the 4th. of this month—was taken upon by general consent out of its time— Petrikin and Mark A Cooper immediately started budgets of burdensome conditions, as amendments, which were sharply debated till the recess— I made a short speech to urge the indispensable necessity of passing the bill in some form before next Saturday. During the recess I went into the Senate where they were debating with much earnestness, the 9th. Section of my revenue bill. Before the recesshad moved to lay the Senate’s Bank Bill on the table, which had been rejected by yeas and naystoafter the recess Cooper’s batch of Amendments in superfetation of Petrikin’s batch was taken up, and divided into parcels, upon each of which yeas and nays were taken—some adopted, some rejected; until about Sunset, when at the motion of Petrikin, the house adjourned.— I came home immediately, and after a very light dinner and went to Mr Alexander Vattemare’s exhibition of Ventriloquism— My wife and granddaughter Mary-Louisa were also there— The sport began with sundry songs and duets by Mr and Miss Manvers, with accompaniment of the Piano—and the recitation of Collins’s Ode on the passions, by Mrs Manvers, very well— Alexandre’s drama is called the adventures of a Ventriloquist or the rogueries of Nicholas, in which he sustained seven parts, old and young, male and female, and imitated the planing of a table, the frying of eggs in a pan, and sundry other strange noises— The House was crowded—and well pleased. I sat between Mrs Paulding, and Mrs B. O. Tayloe— Home between 10 and 11.— Weary.

On attending this morning at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures I found there Davis, Dromgoole, Nisbett and Worthington—just enough to make with me a Quorum— Absent Slade, Tillinghast, Mitchell and Eastman.— Davis referred to the entry on the minutes of 27 April of the decision upon my resolution of 26. March— The entry was that My Resolution was rejected 4. Ayes 5. Nays, whereas the question was upon striking out the words—respecting the protection and encouragement of Manufactures and the internal industry of the Country, and the ayes and nays had been taken on the striking out, and were 5 to 4. considering this as equivalent to a rejection of the Resolution I had so entered the minute— Davis complained that statements had been transmitted to his District, and reproaches against him there for having voted against the Resolution, which he said he had not done. After some discussion, we agreed to meet again Saturday morning; I promised to produce then a statement to be entered on the minute book, and Davis promised to prepare such a statement as he wished to have entered on the minutes— In the house, I did at last succeed in obtaining the reception and an order to print my report on the memorial of the American philosophical Society at Philadelphia— Petrikin objected to the resolution for an Appropriation; and I said I would not press for its immediate consideration— Two or three reports from Committees were received and Pickens was prepared to report an amendment to the Resolution from the Senate, concerning the Muscat and Morocco Presents—but the hour had expired, and the District Bank Bill was resumed—a succession of yeas and nays were taken upon the amendments proposed by Mark A. Cooper and Petrikin, which with a request from Cushing to be excused from voting on one of the amendments—and a discussion thereon continued till the recess— That interval I employed in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, preparing a statement to be entered on the minutes of the Committee, to rectify the misentry of 17. April, but I had not time to finish.

After the recess, there was more discussion upon Cushing’s request to be excused from voting.— which he at last withdrew— The Senate Bill, top-heavy with amendments was denied engrossment as amended, for a third reading by yeas and nays 69 to 90. W. Cost Johnson then moved to take up the Bill reported by the Committee on the District of Columbia, but this required a suspension of the rules—vote 94 to 86. lost— Holleman moved a suspension of the rules to introduce a Bill, allowing the Banks two years to close their affairs Rule suspended 155 to 18.— The Bill was introduced— Underwood, Francis Thomas and M’Kay proposed amendments— I asked for a discrimination in favour of the Patriotic Bank which has not suspended. Warm speech from Dawson. Adjourned at 8. Mrs Thornton here this Evening—

Triplett of Kentucky, attempted to offer a Resolution calling on the Secretary of War to report at the commencement of the next Session of Congress a statement of all the expenses of the Florida War—but Cave Johnson objected because it would make a huge volume. Jenifer obtained an order for printing 5000 copies extra of a report on the Tobacco trade, and the District Bank Bill was immediately taken up by a suspension of the rules again cutting off Pickens’s report concerning the Muscat and Morocco presents— On the Bank Bill; Weller of Ohio had the floor from last Evening; and foamed at the mouth, half froth half-venom against the banks, for about an hour— Then followed a colloquy between Grinnell, and Vanderpoel, to which after sometime objected to its continuance. W. Cost Johnson moved the previous question, which was carried and the main question was first taken upon Underwood’s amendment, also carried 99 to 71. then upon the engrossment of the Bill as amended for a third reading 118 to 67— Previous Question again— Cave Johnson moved to lay the bill on the table—withdrew the motion upon expostulation; but it was immediately renewed by George M. Keim—rejected 70 to 120.— The bill was passed 115 to 75— Then about the title of the Bill— Keim wanted to move an insulting title, but was not allowed.— Hand moved a reconsideration to introduce an abusive title which was read, but which after some altercation he withdrew— The title was then adopted, and the Bill was sent to the Senate— Hoffman moved a suspension of the rules for a resolution of enquiry for copies of a correspondence between Commodore Renshaw, and the Secretary of the Navy, about the dismission of a pump and block maker at the Brooklyn Navy-yard on account of his political opinions. The vote to suspend the rules was 101 to 68. lost for lack of two thirds.— John W. Jones, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means then moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, which was done, and the Navy appropriation Bill was taken up— Governor Lincoln in the Chair— Briggs had been all day, and yesterday in the Chair as Speaker— The Speaker Hunter having been absent—detained at home, it was said, by a sick child.— The Navy Bill was read through, and then taken up by Sections— It was apparently passing through the Committee without note or comment when to start some discussion till the return of the Bank Bill from the Senate I put some enquiry to the Chairman of the Ways and Means, about the amount of the appropriations at several Navy-Yards, which he answered; and then I moved to strike out the words “and for no other purpose whatsoever,” from a section of specified contingencies, the words being as I contended worse than useless and deceptive, holding up the idea of a limitation upon the application of the funds, when in fact there was none— Jones answered and I replied till the recess came when repaired to the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and finished the statement to be entered on the minutes of the Committee to rectify the entry of the 17th. of April— After the recess the Navy Bill was again taken up my proposed amendment was rejected— Crary commenced an attack on the Navy-Board— Thomas’s Bank extinction Bill came back mutilated by the Senate and passed— Adjourned 1/2 past 8. P.M—

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures. Present Adams, Davis, Slade, Tillinghast, Dromgoole, Eastman, Mitchell absent Nisbett and Worthington— I presented the statement which I had drawn up to be entered on the minutes of the proceedings in the Committee on the 17th. of April, upon the Resolution offered by me on the 26th. of March— Davis was unwilling that it should appear on the minutes that the rectification of the former entry was made by his desire, but he did not move to strike it out and it remained— He was unwilling that it should appear that he had objected to the words, “without resort to the expedient of Treasury Notes” he said that Nisbett had made the objection— The name of Davis was accordingly struck out from my Statement and the words “objection was made” were inserted in its place— He then complained that there was any minute entered of yeas and nays, and Dromgoole insisted that the Committee had no right to take yea and nays—nor to keep a journal. Davis made an argument to shew why he had voted to strike out the words relating to the protection of manufactures, and could not see why it should be made to him, and not Mr Eastman.— He desired however that the entry as prepared by me, and now amended should be made on the minutes, and it was so agreed by the Committee I then moved that the Chairman be instructed to report a Resolution, that the prayer of sundry Memorials and Petitions from Pennsylvania referred to the Committee since the 13th. of May, asking a revision of the Tariff for the protection of manufactures, is reasonable and ought to be granted— Davis enquired whether any of the Petitions were from Bucks County (his district.) There were not. Dromgoole said he should oppose this Resolution: but there was no time for the discussion this Morning— The house met at 10 O’Clock— There was a Quorum present, and Governor Lincoln renewed a motion which he had made last Evening that private claims for revolutionary services and pensions should be taken up at 11 O’Clock— But a motion was immediately made to adjourn. Carried by yeas and nays, 66 to 63. I returned immediately to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and made on the minutes of the Committee the entry agreed upon this morning, and a minute of my motion for instructions to report in favour of the Tariff memorials, from Pennsylvania— This kept me till past one O’Clock— Pickens was at the same time writing in the adjoining chamber of the Committee of foreign Affairs, but left the Capitol before me— I walked home, and spent the remainder of the day quietly there. Miss Cutts dined with us, and took Mary-Louisa with her this Evening to Mrs B. O. Tayloe’s to see the splendid fire-works on the President’s Square. The day was celebrated here, at Georgetown, at Alexandria, at Bladensburg, and all over the Country with more intensity than was ever known before— But they were all party celebrations, with none of which I could sympathize— I received a Letter from N. P. Trist, with a Memorial to Congress concerning the case of the Ship Congress, Captain James Eaton, and the Life Protector of his first mate Jason Coghlan.

I attended public worship this morning with Mrs Thornton—my wife, and Mary-Louisa, at the Hall of the House of Representatives, where Mr Cookman preached from Ephesians 2–12 the middle of the verse—“the Commonwealth of Israel”—it was altogether a political discourse, specially suited to the place; and to the day next after the anniversary of Independence.— The argument was that the Hebrew theocracy was a republican Government, and that the Bible is a Book, containing the Supreme Law of Liberty— He illustrated the positions thus assumed, by numerous references to the institutions of the Levitial Law—the special division of the People into twelve tribes, the Separation of the tribe of Levi from all the rest—their peculiar privileges and disabilities—their exclusion from the possession of land, and their dispersion in 48 cities among all the other tribes— Their first government, after Moses and Joshua, by Judges— Then their transition to the rule of kings; effected entirely by the will of the People—disapproved by Samuel—disapproved by God—but yet commanded by him; because demanded by the People.— The remarkable interposition from time to time of Prophets, divinely inspired, but all laymen, and their extraordinary influence upon the affairs of the community— Then under the gospel dispensation, the pre-eminently popular character of the Saviour, and of all his apostles excepting only St. Paul.— He particularly noticed that in the answer of Jesus to the enquiry of the Messengers from John the Baptist, whether he was the Messiah or they should wait for another after enumerating his miracles, the last fact to which he refers and from which he leaves the Baptist to draw his own inference is that the Gospel is preached unto the Poor— Mrs. Thornton thought the Sermon radical, and so it was; and so is the Christian religion— The preaching of Christ was to the multitude— The parable of the rich man and of Lazarus—the comparison of the salvation of a rich man to the passage of a Camel through the eye of a needle— The frequent invectives against the Scribes, Pharisees, Sadducees, Priests and Levites, all shew the tendencies of the system to be democratic— Christianity is indeed above all, the religion. Its first principle historical and theoretical is that all mankind are of one family—descended from one common ancestor, and this is the foundation of the moral and political principle of the natural equality of mankind— From this fact also follows the principle that the state of nature between men is a state of Peace— Here are heads for a lecture or Dissertation— Moral—Political—Religious— I have no time to pursue the thought. After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church— Mr Hawley read the service for the third Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Malachi 3.13. “Your words have been stout against me, saith the Lord; yet ye say, What have we spoken so much against thee 14. Ye have said, it is vain to serve God; and what profit is it that we have kept his ordinance, and that we have walked mournfully before the Lord of hosts?” Mr Hawley takes most of his afternoon texts from the prophets. Evening dark and solitary in my chamber.

I find a physical impossibility of keeping up in this diary with the current of Time, and all my leisure is efforts to redeem arrears. In the house, the Speaker presented a Letter from the Governor of the State of Indiana, enclosing the resignation of Tilghman A. Howard of his seat as a member of the house—as a candidate for the Office of Governor of that State he was obliged to resign his seat here— He was one of the best democrats in the house—had the best— Atherton moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Downing, the delegate from Florida got leave which he had been several days seeking, to introduce a Bill to protect the lives and property of the people of Florida, and to bring the Seminole War to an end.— It was a Bill ofSections constituting a new Government in Florida with power to raise an army of volunteers and giving away all the lands in the Territory— The title was a deception— The Bill was, read twice and Downing moved its reference to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Cave Johnson moved that it should go to the Committee of Military Affairs— Downing made a short, vehement speech against the administration, particularly for the gross mismanagement of the Florida War, and the total failure of protection to the people of the territory— Cave Johnson then moved to lay the Bill on the table—and called the yeas and nays 78 to 39. no Quorum. Second call of the roll 93 to 54. With some difficulty the order was obtained that the Bill should be printed— Pickens wished to offer a Resolution for an appropriation of 25000 dollars for a survey of the Northeastern boundary, but Atherton as acting Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, Jones being absent moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, which was carried— Levi Lincoln in the Chair, and Crary finished in two hours his speech against the board of Navy Commissioners— I said a few words, chiefly to call on the Committee of Naval affairs to know why they had not reported on the plan prepared by the Secretary of the Navy, for abolishing the Navy board under Mallory’s resolution of last February.— It seems the Committee referred the Secretary’s plan to Holleman, Mallory’s successor, and there it has slept. Reed replied effectively to Crary, and Hoffman in a strain of indignant eloquence, vindicated the glories of our Navy, with a rapid review of their atchievements from the War of Independence down to this day. I spent the recess in the Senate chamber, where they were still debating my revenue Bill— After the recess the Navy Appropriation bill was resumed and debated till sunset, when the Committee rose for want of a Quorum, and the house adjourned. Mrs Thornton and Mrs. Talbot were here this Evening.

Triplett of Kentucky offered a Resolution, calling on the Secretary of War to report at the next Session of Congress a detailed account of all the expenses of the Florida War. Cave Johnson objected, because it would make a book as big as a bible— Triplett said he had cast up the sums appropriated and they amounted to 20. 298. 117 dollars, besides the army. M’Kay said that the appropriations since 1. Jany 1836. not only for the Florida War, but for suppressing hostilities of Creeks and Cherokees amounted only to 19 millions, as Cave persisted in his objection Triplett moved a suspension of the rules and called for the yeas and nays; upon which Cave withdrew his objection; and the Resolution was adopted— Pickens, chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs reported a Bill making an appropriation for a survey of the North-eastern boundary—read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— He reported also the Resolution from the Senate authorising the acceptance of the Muscat and Moorish presents, with an amendment authorising only the disposal of the presents— I opposed this, and spoke until the expiration of the morning hour— Vanderpoel moved to pass to the orders of the day while I was speaking— The Bankrupt Bill from the Senate was first taken up— Pickens moved to lay it on the table— There was a call of the house; and the Bill was laid on the table by a vote of 101 to 89.— The house then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Lincoln in the Chair upon the Navy Appropriation Bill— The question pending when the Committee rose last Evening for want of a Quorum, was on a motion of John Reed to insert an appropriation of 60000 dollars to commence the construction of a third steam ship—two having already been constructed— This amendment was carried 77 to 67. Petrikin then moved to strike out a re-appropriation for a dry-dock at New-York, authorised by an Act of 3. March 1835— A debate hereupon arose and continued until the recess; during which after a short visit to the chamber of the Senate, which immediately went into the consideration of executive business— I repaired to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and wrote till the house resumed: and while they were gathering for a quorum Cushing made a didactic speech about blockades, to bring which within the rules of order he moved to strike out the enacting clause of the Navy appropriation Bill, which motion he gave notice he would withdraw as soon as there should be a Quorum present as he did.— The debate upon the Bill was then resumed a dry dock at New York and a third Steam-boat warmly debated till near Sunset when the Bill was reported to the house, passed to be engrossed for a third reading—passed by yeas and nays 154 to 10—and the house adjourned— Evening visit from Mr. Alexandre Vattemare.

I called this morning at the office of the Commissioner of Pensions and left with him a Letter from Anthony Collamore of Pembroke, Massachusetts, and one from Lewis and Pierce with enclosed affidavits concerning the Pension claim of Phebe Reeve— At the House Chapman of Iowa moved a suspension of the rules to fix a day, for considering the business of the Territories, which was carried; and the first day after the general appropriation Bills. W. Cost Johnson moved that the succeeding day should be given to the business of the District of Columbia; but failed for want of a majority of two thirds.— the Muscat and Moorish presents were then resumed and I continued to discourse against both the joint Resolution from the Senate and the amendment proposed by the Committee of foreign Affairs of this house, until the expiration of the morning hour, without concluding when George M Keim called the orders of the day.— Leadbetter of Ohio moved a reconsideration of the vote last evening appropriating money for a dry dock at Brooklyn, New-York and after a stupid speech and some altercation with Stanly, called for the yeas and nays on his motion—rejected 58 to 125. Jones moved a suspension of the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the army appropriation Bill, George Evans of Maine in the Chair, which was done— Curtis Chairman of the Committee of Commerce moved as an amendment an appropriation of 45000 dollars for seven sites to be purchased by the Government for the erection of marine hospitals on the Western Waters: upon which a captious debate upon order was sprung which continued till the recess— The bill to ensure the more faithful execution of the laws relating to the collection of duties on imposts, commonly called my Bill was received from the Senate with numerous amendments, and was at my motion referred to the Committee of manufactures, and as I then inadvertently omitted to move that it should be printed, the Speaker took the chair immediately after the recess, to enable me to make the motion to print, which I did, and which was agreed to.— The question whether an appropriation for Western Marine hospitals was in order, as amendment to an Army Appropriation Bill was debated until after Sunset when the Committee rose for want of a Quorum and the house adjourned—during the recess I visited the Senate chamber, where they were just going into the consideration of Executive business.— I then went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and wrote a Letter of introduction to my Son for Mr Vattemare— I presented this morning the Letter to me from N. P. Trist the Consul at the Havana, with the statement of the case of Jason Coghlan first mate of the ship Congress, Captain Eaton, and Coghlan’s Life protector— Curtis presented also a Memorial against Trist both referred to the Committee of Commerce and to be printed.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures. Present Adams, Dromgoole, Davis, Tillinghast, Slade, Eastman Mitchell. Absent Nisbett and Worthington.— The revenue Bill from the Senate was immediately taken up, and Messrs. Cripps and Maclay, importing merchants at New-York made representations against the passage of the Bill; chiefly urging the Justice of postponing the commencement of the Bill till the 1st. of September. this absorbed the time of the Committee, till the meeting of the house—the Committee adjourned till to-morrow morning at 9. In the house several members had motions to make, and resolutions or petitions to offer, who asked me to indulge them with time for that purpose, but Pickens remonstrated against it, and I was obliged to decline— I spoke about half an hour against the amendment and the Resolution— Pickens made a feeble, and insignificant reply of about 15 minutes to my argument of nearly three hours and closed with calling for the previous question. Cushing asked him to withdraw it, for he had a precedent to produce of authority given by the House to the President of the United States to accept a present from a foreign power— It was a report of W. S. Archer as Chairman of the Committee of foreign Affairs on a medal from the President of the Republic of Columbia— Mark A Cooper moved to lay the whole subject on the table as the best way to defeat the Resolution, but at my request he withdrew the motion— I wished the question to be taken directly by yeas and nays both on the amendment and the Resolution—they were so taken, and the amendment was rejected 69 to 89. and the Resolution by 75 to 86— Gates and Ogle congratulated me on this signal triumph of pure principle, but I told Gates they would reverse it by a reconsideration before to-morrow night— The house then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Evans in the Chair upon the army appropriation Bill— He had decided that Curtis’s motion to insert an item for the purchase of sites for seven marine hospitals on the western waters was in order upon this Bill. from this decision Wise had appealed. After a long renewed discussion of the question this morning the decision of the Chairman was reversed—the bill was then debated on sundry other proposed amendments till the recess— I enquired in the Clerks Office, whether the rejected joint Resolution had been taken by the Clerk to the Senate? No! it had been taken away by a member—they did not know by whom— I went to the Senate chamber where they were upon the mileage Bill—but Mr Clay said he wished to speak on it then or to-morrow and they immediately adjourned— I went to the chamber of the Committee of manufactures and carefully compared the revenue Bill as it had passed the house with the amendments to it adopted by the Senate, and then returned to the house— The army appropriation Bill was again debated on sundry proposed amendments till near Sunset when Stanly took the floor against the standing army and spoke till near 8. O’Clock when the Committee rose the house adjourned— I rode home quite exhausted.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures; present Adams, Dromgoole, Slade, Eastman, Tillinghast, Nisbett, Mitchell and Davis—absent Worthington— The Committee took up the Revenue Bill, as it came from the Senate; read through the part of their Bill, which had been passed by the house, and approved all their amendments to it, with a proposal for a small amendment to the first of them—including a substitute for the 9th. Section much more comprehensive for excluding interested witnesses as incompetent— They also strike out the 15th. Section of the house bill— Mr Nisbett then moved to report the disagreement to the whole thirteen Sections superadded by the Senate which after some discussion he modified to strike out the first of those Sections. The hour had elapsed and the Committee agreed to meet again, at 9 to morrow Morning— In the House, no sooner was the Journal read, than Clifford of Maine, holding in his hand the rejected joint Resolution from the Senate which it was the duty of the Clerk to have taken to the Senate yesterday, before Noon, moved a reconsideration of the vote by which it was rejected— I enquired why the Resolution had not been transmitted yesterday to the Senate, upon which a long debate succeeded— I offered a Resolution, that the Clerk of the House by delivering privately to a member a joint Resolution of the Senate—rejected by the House had violated his official duty—and I produced Section 16 of Jefferson’s Manual as authority— It is perfectly explicit— All the screws of party machinery were now used. Motions to lay on the table previous questions,—appeals from the decision of the chair—until the administration majority succeeded in smothering all debate and were panting to reject by yeas and nays my Resolution, when to their great mortification I withdrew it.— Clifford’s motion to reconsider was then carried 108 to 54.— Horace Everett endeavoured in vain to introduce an amendment— Naylor moved a reconsideration of the vote yesterday which rejected the amendment proposed by the Committee of foreign Affairs—lost 70 to 75 because several members mistook the question— Clifford’s amendment striking out the authority to the President to accept, but authorising him to sell and put the proceeds into the Treasury was carried 82 to 76 and the honest decision of yesterday was reversed by a smaller number than it was passed—and the Resolution was adopted 82 to 70.— The Resolution for exchange of books was also passed and the recess came before the morning hour commenced— After the recess, which I passed in the chamber of the Committee of manufactures, there was a long struggle for a Quorum, then a few reports from Committees received and then Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Evans in the Chair upon the army appropriation Bill— Stanly resumed and concluded his speech against the increase of the army— I left him speaking about 8. O’Clock and came home— The house adjourned between 9 and 10.

Mr Hassler came this morning much aggrieved at some amendment made yesterday in the Senate to an appropriation bill providing that a sum ofdollars for the harbour of Mobile shall be taken from the appropriation for the Survey of the Coast; which he intreated me to have rectified in the House— HR.U.S. Curtis made an effort to have Hillen’s Bill to repeal the Pilot Law referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, which failed. The Committees were called for reports till the expiration of the morning hour, when the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, George Evans in the Chair upon the Army Appropriation Bill— The item of 300000 dollars for the suppression of Indian hostilities in Florida, was under consideration— Waddy Thompson, Chairman of the Committee of Military Affairs insisted that it would not be half enough, and that his bill for raising 1600 men more for the army and the Bill for the armed occupation of Florida, and yet more, would be indispensably necessary to carry on the War in Florida— Biddle then took the floor and opposed the appropriation in a speech of nearly three hours exposing the imbecility and profligacy of the management of this war concluding with a severe castigation of Van Buren for the base Slanders in his globe, against Biddle himself— He was followed by Hiram P. Hunt of New-York till the recess and after the recess till 6 O’Clock, still further exposing the mismanagement of the War— Then came William O. Butler of Kentucky who having been one of General Jacksons aids in the New Orleans campaign of 1814. now burst out for the first time in a panegyric of an hour and a half upon General Jackson, upon the present administration, upon the army, and all its successive commanders, Gaines Clinch Scott, Jesup, Call, Macomb, Taylor and Armistead, who have succeeded each other, and finished by dismission, resignation or court of inquiry upon their glorious atchievements in the War.— At the dusk of Evening, the Committee rose, and the house adjourned— I had been some time on the steps of the Eastern front of the Capitol, listening to the pleasant music of the Marine Corps band— Our Coachman Thomas had hurt his right hand so that he could not drive his horses— So my wife sent a hack to the Capitol for me, which took me home— I then went to the Theatre to see Fanny Ellsler the fashionable idol dancing girl of the passing hour— Jenifer had promised to keep a seat for me, in the parquet; but I found it preoccupied by Mr Chinn. He insisted upon giving it up to me; but I found the heat in it so stifling that I was obliged to leave it, and go up to the second row of boxes, in one of which I saw Dr Sutherland of Philadelphia sitting alone— The play began with a poor farce called shocking Events. Then came Fanny Ellsler and Monsieur Sylvain, said to be an Irishman named Sullivan, in a poor Ballet called La Tarantule— A song by a man named Hall, and La Cracovienne, a Polish dance by Fanny.— The exhibition of lascivious attitudes is the unrivalled excellence of Fanny— Posies of Roses were cast from the boxes at her feet upon the Stage. She was called out, and gave thanks to the People.

I entered yesterday upon the seventy-fourth year of my age; and I have now lived as long since the decease of my mother as she had lived when I was born— I am deeply sensible of the duty of beginning in earnest to wean myself from the interests and affections of this world, and of preparing myself for my departure to that which is to come—and yet the day of yesterday was so absorbed in worldly business, and worldly pleasure that not a moment of it was left for self-admonition or for meditation— The truth is I adhere to the world, and to all its vanities from an impulse altogether involuntary, and cannot by any exercise of my will realize that I can have but very few days more to live, and that I have nothing better or more urgent to do than to pack up and make ready for my voyage.— I might have taken, another warning to the same effect by attendance this morning at the Presbyterian Church where it was Communion day, and where Mr Wood preached from Luke 22.19. [“]And he took bread, and gave thanks, and brake it, and gave unto them saying, This is my body which is given for you: this do in remembrance of me.” A strictly adapted communion discourse, but not very impressive— The communicants were very few—the members of other churches present were invited to partake, but as I knew this was not intended to include the members of Unitarian Churches, I did not avail myself of the invitation— Mr Wood invited also the members of other Churches present who might abstain from joining in the Communion service to stay while it should be performed; but if any should find that inconvenient, they would have the opportunity of withdrawing while a hymn, which he gave out should be sung— I accordingly withdrew—and after dinner attended at St. John’s Church— There the Evening service for the fourth Sunday after Trinity was read by a Stranger, Who preached from Exodus 32.29—[“]For Moses had said, Consecrate yourselves to-day to the Lord, even every man, upon his son, and upon his brother; that he may bestow upon you a blessing this day.” The preacher took only the under-scored parts of the verse for his text; and the self consecration to the Lord, which he urged upon his auditory, had no affinity with that which Moses enjoined upon the Israelites in his text— The self consecration of the Israelite was to be effected by putting to death his Son and his brother, and the historical part of the transaction when this self consecration was commanded and executed seemed little adapted to recommend the same process in a very different manner at this day. Where then is the practical application of the precept? how is a Christian to consecrate himself to the Lord to day, in order that he may obtain a blessing this day? surely not by slaying his son and his brother, but by forsaking his sins and turning to righteousness— The preachers exhortation was warm and earnest— Evening at home, in solitude.

There is a physical impossibility of keeping my daily record up with the current of time and I am reduced to the necessity of resorting to the substitute of an abridgement— I attended this morning at 9 the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Slade, Dromgoole, Nisbett, Worthington, Mitchell, Davis, Tillinghast. Absent Eastman— Messrs. Hadden, Hutton and Pattison, Merchants from New-York attended the Committee and read a remonstrance against the Bill which they left with the Committee— They had attended the Committee also on Saturday; and had no small altercation with J. N. Barker the Comptroller, without knowing him— He was then also at the request of J. Davis in attendance; but not this morning— Hadden and Pattison are both Englishman importing merchants, and have had several suits against the Collector. Hutton is an American agent for a French house. Haddan brought me a Letter of recommendation from Joseph Blunt; but he is a Yorkshire Clothier.— They occupied nearly the whole of the Committee’s time this morning, and when they withdrew Nisbett moved that the 17th. and subsequent Sections should be limited not to commence till the 1st. of September, which all the members present voted for except myself— Nisbett then moved to strike out the 17th Section. Ayes Nisbett, Dromgoole, Mitchell— Nays Adams, Tillinghast, Worthington, Slade, Davis— Nisbett then moved to strike out the 19th Section— Adjourned to meet at 9 to-morrow morning— HR.U S. Chapman of Alabama, moves to suspend the rules, for a resolution requiring the judiciary Committee to report forthwith on Lieutt. Hooe’s case, who is and who shall not be witnesses on Courts Martial Call of the House 181 members answered.— For suspension of the rules 110 to 67 not two thirds, but these 110 were ready for a Law to exclude all coloured men from giving testimony on Courts Martial— The whole Kinderhoek Phalanx and all the Southern Whigs would have voted for it.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Evans in the Chair on the Army Appropriation Bill— Amendment of 300000 dollars for suppressing indian hostilities—including arrearages from 1836 to 1839— Graves, two hours and a half in reply to the Speech of Butler of Kentucky last Saturday—followed by John Downing the Delegate from Florida till the recess— I went into the Senate chamber, and there meeting the demoniac squint and hearing the hateful voice of Benjamin Tappan— I repaired to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and read House Document 49. on Anti Tariff judicial constructions— After recess Downing resumed a whig invective of two hours against the Van-Buren administration, especially for the mismanagement of the Florida War— Underwood of Kentucky followed till the dusk of Evening, chiefly in defence of Jesup and the use of the blood-hounds— About 8 O’Clock the members having drop’d as usual till there was no Quorum the Committee rose and the House adjourned.

Met the Committee of Manufactures. Present Adams, Nisbett, Dromgoole, Davis, Mitchell, Slade, Worthington Tillinghast;—absent Eastman.— Much discussion upon the Senate’s Additional Bill—one amendment to the 19th. Section carried, and one lost 4 to 4— Adjourned to meet at 8. to-morrow Morning. H.R.U.S. William W. Chapman delegate from the Territory of Iowa, struggled hard for a suspension of the rules to get to morrow fixed for the consideration of territorial business— He had obtained an order for the day next after the general appropriation Bills; but as these now threaten to absorb all the remainder of the Session, he appealed to the justice and generosity of the house, for one territorial day—to-morrow— Petrikin objected— Chapman asked for the yeas and nays, which were refused and his motion to suspend the rules was rejected— James Cooper of Gettysburg Pennsylvania moved a suspension of the rules for a preamble and 3. Resolutions directing the insurance of the public buildings against fire— Suspension rejected. Hoffman presented Memorials from the Chamber of Commerce and the board of trade at New-York remonstrating against the passage of the Revenue Bill— Reuben Chapman of Somerville, Morgan County Alabama, moved a suspension of the rules, for a Resolution instructing the judiciary Committee to report a Bill, prohibiting the enlistment of negroes or coloured persons in the army or navy of the United States— Stanly, Botts and Proffit asked to be excused from voting on this motion to suspend; each for reasons assigned—all refused. Stanly claimed to have his reasons entered on the Journals—refused. Rules suspended— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union; Evans in the Chair. Army appropriation Bill—amendment 300000 dollars for the suppression of Indian hostilities in Florida. Some remarks of explanation concerning proceedings of the Committee on Military Affairs, between Governeur Kemble, Waddy Thompson and James Monroe. Then James I M’Kay, spoke about two hours, in justification of himself, and in reply to Stanly, upon the increase of the army from 6000 to 12510 men, and especially the increase of July 1838 reported and supported by M’Kay then Chairman of the Military Committee— I took the floor at a quarter before 2. and spoke till the recess, which I passed in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, examining George M. Keim’s Militia Committee standing army report— At 4. P.M. I resumed and spoke till 8. against the increase of the army—the 1600 men bill, the armed occupation Bill, the Secretary of War’s standing army Militia project, and Keim’s absurd and profligate Militia Committee report. Fahrenheit at 90. I closed, thoroughly exhausted— There was a Quorum, and a motion to adjourn—which failed— J. M. Botts followed. I left him speaking and it was half past 11. when the house adjourned. I found R. Cutts junr and his sister at our house. Mrs Hopkinson and Mrs Biddle had been here

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures at 8. A.M. all the members present. Revenue bill from the Senate—debated Sections 17–27. Nisbett and Dromgoole battering on one side— Slade and Mitchell, nibbling on the other, object to every section and move numerous amendments— Section 20 to be struck out. Adjourn to meet again to morrow morning at 8. HR.U.S.— Stanly moves to amend the journal by inserting the reasons which he offered yesterday for asking to be excused from voting on Chapman’s motion to suspend the rules for a resolution instructing the judiciary Committee to report forthwith a Bill prohibiting the employment of negroes or coloured men in the army or navy— Dromgoole remonstrated— Banks moved a call of the house refused yeas 23— Nays 102 against amending the journal, but Stanly’s reasons are entered upon it— Motion to suspend the rules for a report on the abuse of the franking privilege—and another to take up the amendments of the Senate to the Mileage bill, both lost— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Evans in the Chair on the Army Appropriation Bill and the amendment of 300000 dollars for the suppression of Indian hostilities in Florida— Wise made a speech of 3 hours on the Florida War, chiefly in reply to Butler of Kentucky, who had pretended that it was an abolition War— Wise charged that it was a kidnapper war— He quoted the Sportsman’s Calendar Vol. 2 and Somerville’s Chase upon the blood-hounds— Keim followed for about half an hour in reply to me—brings in Cicero’s Offices to prove that cedant arma togae is good Latin and straining to be very bitter in retaliation upon me— Quotes my Lectures on Rhetoric and Dermot M Morrogh till the recess.— In the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, I had some conversation with Messrs. Wasson and Cairnes and another person from the custom house at New-York.— Before returning to the house I borrowed in the Library a Volume of the Delphin Cicero containing the second Philippic, and a volume of Foote’s works containing the Mayor of Garratt— Keim soon finished his retaliatory, and I replied; occupying not more than ten minutes, partly by reading the Scene in the Mayor of Garratt when Major Sturgeon proves his scholarship by the quotation cedant arma togae, with which I observed the Chairman of the Militia Committee might draw his parallel— Triplett followed and about Sunset the Bill was reported to the house and passed— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union again, George C. Dromgoole in the Chair on the Indian Appropriation Bill— Marine Corps Band Music John Bell— I left the House at 1/2 past 8 and came home.

Mrs Hopkinson and Mrs Biddle came to our house yesterday to spend a few days with my wife and Mary. when I came home last Night they were at the theatre where they had gone to see Fanny Ellsler. I met them at breakfast this morning and immediately after was obliged to go to meet the Committee of Manufactures at 8. A.M— Present Adams Nisbett, Dromgoole, Davis, Tillinghast, Slade, Worthington and Mitchell— Absent Eastman. The Committee concluded the examination of the amended Bill from the Senate, and authorised the Chairman to report it with amendments to the house— HR.U.S. John Campbell, Chairman of the Committee of Elections, produced a Report concluding with a Resolution that the five Members already palmed upon the house, are entitled to their Seats; as members from New Jersey. He first moved a suspension of the rules to present the report yeas and naystonot two thirds— He then claimed to present it, as a privileged case— The Speaker decided that it was not a case of privilege. The house reversed his decision, and the report was received— A minority report signed by 4 members of the Committee was presented by Fillmore— Proffit insisted that both reports should be read which consumed the time till the recess and more. After the recess while the quorum was forming I presented the Report of the Revenue bill with the amendments which were order to be printed, from the Committee of Manufactures— Campbell had moved the printing of the majority and minority reports on the New Jersey election, and the journal of the Committee, and had called the previous question—but on hearing the minority report read, which reflected with great justice and severity upon the profligate proceedings of the majority, he modified his motion to print, leaving out the minority report, and still insisting upon the previous question— This dirty trick produced a burst of indignation from the whigs upon whigs, and Campbell covered the cheat, by playing the bully to cover the cheat. The yeas and nays were taken 3 several times; on printing the majority report, the journal and the minority report— They were all carried—the last by a meagre majority— Campbell had moved to make the majority report the order of the day for next Monday but Jameson of Missouri, a Savage in temper, in looks, and I have no doubt in blood moved to adopt the resolution, declaring the 5 spurious members entitled to the Seats and demanded the previous question— It was carried, and the resolution itself without hearing evidence or parties by a vote of 102 to 22. only 2 more than a quorum about 70 members present withholding their votes. Never was a cause lost by more dastardly submission than that of the voting whigs in this case—and they alone are responsible for the consummation of this villainy. Adjourned about 9 PM. I came home and found Mrs Henderson and her Son here— Mrs Hopkinson and Mrs Biddle— Fahrenheit at 90.

Short morning visit from Coll Sylvanus Thayer now superintendent of the fortifications in Boston harbour; works always in progress and never to be completed. The visit shorter for another at the same time from Mr Talley a methodist minister from New Jersey, soliciting a contribution for a methodist Church at Somerville in that State. Mrs Hopkinson, Mrs Biddle, and Richard Cutts junr. rode with me to the Capitol. H.R.U.S. Sundry motions to amend the journals of yesterday and the day before which occasioned much altercation— The motions to amend were all rejected by the house, but were entered upon the journal— Campbell Chairman of the Committee of Elections reported as a case of privilege in favour of the Election of Osmyn Baker, for the 6th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— Unanimous— The petitioners against him never produced a particle of evidence to sustain their petition— Report of a majority of the Committee in favour of Charles Nayler for the 3d. Congressional District of Pennsylvania— Minority Report in favour of Charles J. Ingersoll— Reports and testimony laid on the table and ordered— Petrikin moved an amendment to the resolution of the majority report declaring Naylor duly elected; to strike out his name and insert that of Ingersoll.— Campbell said he would call up the Reports to-morrow.— Graham of North-Carolina made a personal explanation to expose a forgery of his frank to send into his district budgets of one of the speeches of Alexander Duncan— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union George C. Dromgoole, drunk, in the Chair— Indian Appropriation Bill— Bell opposes an item of appropriation for the removal of the Winebago Indians. Everett, John W. Jones, Crary, Bell, till the recess.— A young man by the name of Robert Morris, from Tioga County New-York accosted me in the passage without the Hall to enquire, if in Massachusetts or any other of the New England States he could, obtain a divorce from his wife— He married her here about a year since—her name was Williams—but he had been deceived. She had deserted him, and lost her character— He appeared to be much distressed— I referred him to Mr Tillinghast, where I supposed if any where he could obtain his divorce— After the recess George W. Hopkins was in the chair instead of Dromgoole— A Statement from the Secretary of the Treasury dated 1 July, 1840, and not presented by the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means to the house till the 15th. was this day first laid, printed on the tables of the members, avowing a deficit of 4 1/2 millions of dollars—Seneca tribe Treaty not produced—D. D. Barnard. I left the house at 10. P.M Charles Shepard then speaking— The House sat till near 2. of the morning. Fahrenheit at 90.

The item of appropriation for the execution of the spurious and fraudulent Treaty with the Seneca without any communication by the President of the Treaty itself to the house, occasioned a warm debate last Evening, between John W. Jones and Vanderpoel, the Minion on one side, and Barnard, J. Q. Adams, R. Garland, Biddle, and Evans— Jones, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, did not know that the communication of the Treaty was necessary— It was not necessary to this house— A Bill came from the Senate to authorize the President to raise 3500 volunteers for two years to serve in Florida— Upwards of 50 private Bills which had passed through the house came back from the Senate, rejected in a batch— Bill from the Senate for a survey by Commissioners of the Northeastern boundary, referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Mr Stone of the house of Lawrence and Stone came to me to express their great anxiety for the passage of the Revenue-bill; but it is too late— This morning Elizabeth Pierce came and made enquiries concerning her, and her Sister’s claim; upon which I could give them no encouragement. Ross, one of the Stone-cutters, came with a petition for compensation, from March to May last, during which their work was suspended. After consultation he concluded by my advice to get the petition presented first to the Senate. H.R.U.S. motion to suspend the rules, for a resolution to pay the ejected members from New-Jersey. lost— Ramsay moved to suspend the rules for a Resolution to pay Charles J. Ingersoll for his expenses in procuring testimony— I asked that the Revenue bill from the Senate with the amendments reported by the Committee of Manufactures should be referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union—objection made, I moved the suspension of the rules— Yeas 90. nays 60. not two thirds—lost. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. G. W. Hopkins in the Chair— Indian appropriation Bill. Two or three questions on amendments taken and carried by yeas and nays—then the Bill reported to the House and passed.— Motion to reconsider, to introduce an amendment 5000 dollars for a new Cherokee Treaty to avert a Cherokee War, said to be otherwise inevitable—twice rejected. Bill from the Senate 25,000 dollars to survey the North eastern boundary, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Russell in the Chair— I moved as an amendment a Second section appropriating 20000 dollars for magnetic and meteorological observations—rejected by yeas and nays 34 to 96.— Recess— Evening Session Army Bill. Amendments from the Senate Suspensions of the 16th. rule— Outfit of Minister Resident at Constantinople— I came home with Mrs Hopkinson Mrs Biddle and Mr Barnard at 11. P.M.

Last evening there was a sharp debate on the deficit in the revenue, and the means of providing for it. Preparations for quitting 3. March 1841 Power given to P.U.S to postpone payments at his discretion— Sauve qui peut— Clifford was in the Chair of the Committee of the whole, and Briggs Quasi-Speaker. Vanderpoel the minion gone. D. D. Barnard was followed by Proffit—violent denunciation of Van Buren— I left Thomas Smith of Indiana answering his colleague, and the House adjourned at Midnight— This morning I attended public worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives. Mr Cookman preached from Ecclesiastes 9.11. [“]I returned, and saw, under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all—” A valedictory discourse, specially addressed to the members of Congress, not more than ten or twelve of whom were present. I was belated, and he was just beginning the Sermon when I entered the Hall. The text was well chosen, and the discourse well suited to soften animosities and assuage Mortifications. Indeed the race has not been during this Session to the swift, nor the battle to the strong. The most important and the worst measures of the Administration have been carried through the house by the most contemptible men in it— Mr Cookman illustrated his text by many references to historical scriptural events. The discomfiture and destruction of Pharaoh— The death of Abimelech slain by a tile cast from the hand of a woman.— That of Goliath, by the pebble from the sling of the stripling David. the crumbling to atoms of the walls of Jericho at the blast of the ramshorns blown by the priests, and the hanging of Haman, upon the gallows fifty cubits high which he had erected for Mordecai the jew, were all adduced as examples, that the battle is not always to the strong.— But the chief exhortation of the preacher was to mutual forbearance and forgiveness of which there is great need and little hope— Mr Saltonstall and Mr Vattemare visited us before dinner, and Richard Cutts junr, and his Sister with Mr Hodgson in the evening.— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the service for the fifth Sunday after Trinity, and commented upon the denomination of a living stone given to the Lord Jesus Christ in 1. Peter 2.4. but he did not read the verse, nor was there much impressiveness or significancy in his remarks— Mrs Biddle with Mrs John Adams spent the Evening at Mr B. O. Tayloe’s and Mrs Hopkinson with us here— The pressure upon my time continues unabated, and arrears follow.

I attended at the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, but no other Member of the Committee was there. H.R.U.S. Ramsay moved to suspend the Rules for a Resolution to pay the Clerk and Officers of the House, two months extra pay, and other gratuities as the Senate have done with their Officers and called the previous question This was the Clerk’s premium pudicitiae, or price of prostitution— But it was rejected 38 to 141. Toland moves a reconsideration, for the gratuities but leaving out the Clerk—but Cave Johnson moves to lay the whole on the table. Carried 91 to 62. Senate’s amendments to the Navy-Appropriation Bill— The Senate insist on their appropriation for the survey of Apalachicola Bay, pilfered from the Coast survey. Evans moves to insist and ask a conference. I move to adhere and let the Senate ask a conference. Jameson the half-breed moves to recede and the previous question. House refuse to recede 89 to 91. I withdrew my motion to adhere—the House insisted and asked a conference— Jones moved that the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union be discharged from the consideration of the Senate’s amendments to the army appropriation Bill, at 1/2 past 2. O’Clock carried 120 to 44. and to take them up in the House at 4. P.M.— Carried 111 to 31. yeas and nays refused. Rules suspended— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Clifford in the Chair, on the Senate’s amendments to the army appropriation Bill— Amendments debated— Stanly’s visit to the Treasury— His conversation with the Secretary— Called to order— Appeals from the Speaker’s decision— Debates and withdraws his appeal. Bell, Wise, Cushing, Tillinghast Garret Davis against giving the postponing power to the President.— Barnard— W. B. Calhoun moves to except the works at the Springfield, and Harper’s ferry armouries. 33 to 64. No Quorum. recess. I answered an invitation from my niece Mrs De Wint, to attend at her residence, Cedar grove, fishkill landing on the Banks of the Hudson river New York, and witness the nuptials of her daughter Louisa, with Mr Whittemore. Minutes of the Select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest Bill.— At the Senate chamber in search of the Bill for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell—it had passed. Evening Session— Army Bill taken up in the house. Outfit to Constantinople rejected— Misappropriation of the Coast survey fund rejected. Conference and agreement. Supplementary joint Resolution from the Senate relating to the District Banks law. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Underwood in the Chair—upon the West Point Academy Appropriation Bill— Amendment proposed by Curtis about the pay of Custom House Officers— Not in order. Christopher H. Williams a Tennessee whig starts a snappish and growling debate against the West Point Academy After two hours of snarling, the previous question was called and carried, and the Bill passed— Postponing power granted to the President till the 3d. of March 1841. Albert Smith attacks the Bank of the United States. Cooper, John W. Jones, Evans, Grinnell.— Fortification Bill passed— The Ladies went off at 11.— Some time after Midnight Adjourned by yeas and nays. 79 to 63. Walk home.
Close of the first Session of the 26th. Congress.

H.R.U.S. met at 10. A.M— Large Quorum. I moved that the Committee of Manufactures, should be discharged from the further consideration of all matters referred to them, and upon which they have not reported— Call from various quarters for the same motion in behalf of all the Committees— Changed for a call on the Committees to report.— Nevertheless the general order of discharge was entered upon the Journal— The Committee on Indian Affairs did make a report— Motion that it should be printed— Cave Johnson objects on the pretence that the House knew not the contents of the Report, but in reality out of mere spite against Bill, Chairman of the Committee of Indian Affairs, the Reporter— The motion to print was taken by yeas and nays, and not obtaining a vote of two thirds was lost, and the Report was laid on the table. Orders of the day. I called up, out of turn, the Resolution which passed the Senate yesterday for paying arrears to the workmen on the Treasury building, from March till May last, while their labour was suspended by the Commissioner of Public Buildings; because he had neither money nor credit to pay them. John W. Davis of Indiana objected—upon which I moved a suspension of the Rules, and stated the hardship of the case of the workmen, and the equity of their claim—deprived of their occupation not by their own will, but by the Commissioner of the public buildings himself. Davis withdrew his objection— I moved an amendment to include the workmen on the Patent building, carelessly omitted in the Resolution from the Senate—carried without opposition— Resolution passed and the Senate immediately concurred in the Amendment— Charles Fisher of North-Carolina said as this was completed—that is a good work done; and one of the workman in the outer passage way thanked me for giving them a lift— This was the last I heard of it. Orders of the day again— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Briggs in the Chair— Fortification Bill. Suspension of the 17th. joint rule—that no bill shall be sent to the President on the last day of the Session— One hour, the last of the Session allowed for the consideration of Bills relating to the Territories.— The omnibus Bill was in the mean time passed. At 1. P.M. Committee of the whole on the Territorial Bills— Casey in the Chair— The first Bill taken up was that to raise 1600 men additional to the army, to suppress Indian hostilities in Florida Objection made that it was not a territorial bill— Casey so decided; and upon appeal his decision was sustained by the Committee— Several territorial Bills passed the Committee; but when the Speaker resumed the Chair, the closing messages to the Senate and the President passed, and when 2. O’Clock came, while the yeas and nays were being called on a Territorial bill, the Speaker declared the House adjourned to the first Monday in December next. I invited Dawson, King, Ogle, Sergeant, Wise, W. C Johnson, Cushing, Saltonstall, Stanly, Curtis, Hoffman and Monroe, and A. Vattemare to our house this Evening— Walk home— Large Evening party— Session closed. [symbols] for Hope still left.

Mrs Hopkinson and Mrs Biddle left us this morning, and returned to Philadelphia— Morning visit from Coll. Thomas who told me an anecdote respecting my next door neighbour Albion K Parris and his Son Albert W. Parris, receiving a sum of 90 dollars due to a Frenchman named Albert Paris, upon which I reserve my judgment. Mrs John Adams taking her daughter Mary Louisa with her, went to Mrs. Adelaide Hellen’s and executed indentures of partition, with her brothers Johnson and Walter Hellen, of the real Estate in this City left them by their father— I went with them and leaving them at Mrs Hellen’s proceeded to the Capitol, and found at my Seat in sleepy hollow corner of the Representative Hall, the two Volumes of Dallas’s history of the Maroon War in Jamaica which I returned to the Library of Congress and squared my account there— I found Mr Rice Garland in the Hall, at his seat— He was some months since appointed a Judge of the Supreme Court of the State of Louisiana, and then offered me his Seat when he should leave it at the close of the Session, which I accepted— Mr Garland now said he would efface his name, and write mine in its place, but in looking down upon the desk, he found the name of Jesse A. Bynum, already written over his own: Bynum is the man who insulted and would have stab’d him in that very seat.— Garland now immediately took his penknife out of his pocket erased the name of Bynum, and wrote mine, “in person,” in its place.— But I expect Bynum will take it if he can, the next Session— In the Clerk’s Office, I took a printed copy of the Act for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell, and took leave of Stanly whom I found there searching for documents for an electioneering tour in North-Carolina— Returning home I took up Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary-Louisa, at Mrs Hellen’s. We had morning visits from Mrs Cranch and her brother James Greenleaf, a man of 75 whose life has been a great and long disappointment to himself; and the ruin of most of his family. Also from Mr Vattemare, who is imprudently projecting another exhibition of Ventriloquism at the Theatre— His equivocal position has raised up numerous adversaries against him; and in his projected exchanges he has succeeded as it were by a miracle.— He teazes me continually to write for him a dedication of his American Album, without being aware that his excessive and extravagant estimate of my influence and character is precisely that which raises envy, and jealousy and malignity against himself— His collections here have been very considerable—for the royal library—for the courts of Justice—for the Mint of France, for the City of Paris and for other Institutions, from all of which he expects that returns of at least equal value will be made.— Mary-Louisa, went to a dancing evening party at her school-mistress, Miss Breschard’s. The Session of Congress having now closed the pressure of my occupations will now be to retrieve the arrears of this Diary, and to make preparation for my departure homeward, for all which I allow myself a week from this day—

Morning visit from John H. Sherburne; a workman of all dirty work for Kinderhoek, who has been for some time following his vocation in Florida. He told me that the appropriation of 300000 dollars in the army Bill for the suppression of Indian hostilities in Florida, was a scandalous waste of public money, and that no imagination could conceive the corruptions in the management of the Florida War which he had witnessed, and of which he might have added he was himself no inconsiderable part. He said that he himself had brought in Oseola, under the faith of a white flag, which Jesup violated by detaining him as a prisoner— That within two hours after Oseola died his head was severed from his body—sold for 3000 dollars and sent to New-York for public exhibition there— That then an offer was made of 1000 dollars a week for seven weeks of such exhibition; but by the interposition of some one who threatened a popular movement of indignation against it if it should be attempted, it was prevented and the head sent back to St. Augustine, where it is now in the possession of Doctor (name not remembered)— He said Oseolas body was also boiled down, and the bones were taken out of it and dried, and carried to Charleston South-Carolina— Sherburne is so notorious a liar, that no one believes a word that he says, unless otherwise vouched— He further told me that he had found among his fathers books a History of the Administration of John Adams, by John Wood, which he had been advised to republish; he understood that the whole Edition had been bought up and suppressed by the family of Alexander Hamilton— He had lent the book to Mr Kendall who thought it immensely interesting, and he had been assured that if republished at New-York, ten thousand copies of it would be sold in that city alone—but that he would not publish it without my consent— I told him I should neither give my consent or dissent to its publication— I cared nothing about it— I had known the book nearly forty years for a worthless budget of lies compiled by a renegade English literary poacher, once bought up and suppressed not by the Hamilton’s but by Aaron Burr, and afterwards published by treachery to him— I called at the Bank of the Metropolis; a desolation—and at the Treasury where I received 1060 dollars in Treasury Notes— Also 1200 dollars, all at 5 per cent interest, 40 dollars in half eagles, and 1. dollar 60 cents in silver, making my pay and mileage for the last Session of Congress 2241 dollars 60 cents— Mileage reduced by the Committee from 509 to 472 miles.— Called and left cards at Mr Bodisco’s the Russian, Baron Maréschal’s the Austrian, and Monsieur de Bacourt’s the French Ministers— Began packing books and papers— Afternoon and Evening, heavy rain.

Mr Frye was here this morning and spoke to me of my private concerns in this City which have been for several years under his management and care— They are very troublesome, and during the Session of Congress it is utterly impossible for me to give any attention to them. The Columbian Mills, instead of being as I had flattered myself they would be, when I bought them a profitable property, are a perpetual drain upon my income; and the course of business has so changed by the multiplication of flour mills all over the Country, the decay of Georgetown, and the Baltimore and Ohio Rail road that the value of the Estate has almost dwindled down to nothing. Mr Frye spoke about the insurance of my property here which I have neglected for several years. I gave him the policy upon Mrs John Adams’s house; which expired in Novr. 1838 when we left it— I gave him also Dr Laurie’s Letter of 9. Octr. 1837.— He has a judgment against Mrs Doyne— He promised me a statement of his account before I leave this City next week— Mr Joshua Dodge came to take leave— He goes to-morrow Northward to embark again for Europe, as an Agent to negotiate with the Governments in the North of Europe for the reduction of duties upon Tobacco— The Cultivators of that weed have been these three or four years agitating the Country with their claims and Dodge has been once upon a Tobacco mission which proved partially successful. On the last day of the last Session Jenifer gave notice that unless the European duties on Tobacco shall be reduced before the 1st. of next January he will ask leave to introduce a Bill for levying countervailing duties— There seems to be an opinion creeping in that the tobacco interest which embraces six or seven central States, may be brought over to the protective system— Dodge earnestly requested me to peruse his report on the taxation of tobacco in England, France, Germany and Russia; and to give particular attention to a large tobacco-trade Document of which 5000 extra copies were recently ordered to be printed by the House of Representatives— Mr Dodge is going to Coll. Mercer’s near Annapolis, and took charge of his handkerchief, which he lent to sling my arm, on theof May when my shoulder was dislocated. I delivered at the Madisonian Office a packet addressed to it under a blank cover directed to me, and with a superscription on the packet itself requesting me to send it to the Post-Office which I declined— Mr Gales was not at the National Intelligencer Office— I called at Charles R. King’s Picture Gallery, and saw Sully’s Portrait of Queen Victoria— King says that it is not properly estimated in this Country, and that Sully will take it back to England— With my wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary-Louisa, I spent the Evening with Mr Thomas B. Johnson. Returning home I found Dr Frederick Hall here, with several Letters to foreign corresponding members of the American Historical Society, to inform them that the Society itself is merged in the National Institution for the promotion of Science.

I called at the Office of the third Auditor Peter Hagner, with a printed copy certified by J. L Martin, Chief Clerk in the Department of State, of the Act for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell, and his Power to me to receive the money— Mr Hagner said that for the settlement of the account, it would be necessary for him to have the papers upon which the act was passed— I said I would procure them myself and he gave me an order for them upon Hugh A. Garland, Clerk of the House of Representatives— At the approach of Sunset, I went with my wife, Mrs John Adams and Mary-Louisa, to the Capitol, where I found only one of the under clerks of the house, and he could not find the papers— I left the order with him, and directions to send the papers to my house Monday Morning. We heard the Music of the Marine band. I exchanged a passing greeting with Baron Maréchal the Austrian Minister, and Mr Martini the Chargé d’Affaires from Holland—and with Mr Alexandre Vattemare from whom I cannot escape— He was after me two or three times yesterday, and will call again, Monday Morning.— After a ride round by the Navy-Yard we returned home, and I finished the day in drudgery to assort and file my papers. I have hundreds of Letters unanswered, and not even duly filed— Loose public documents and pamphlets and newspapers innumerable.— I am packing up four large boxes of them, and of books to send by water round to Boston, which is another grievous trouble— At least 49 50ths. of my unanswered Letters, are from total strangers, and utterly worthless.— Multitudes of Applications to attend public meetings; and to deliver Orations—Addresses, Lectures, to Lyceums, Literary Societies and political gatherings of the People.— Household cares are superadded more and more burdensome with the advance of years— Anxieties for the journey for the return home, and for those I am to leave behind.— An hourly reminded and daily deepening consciousness of decay in body and mind; an unquenchable thirst for repose, yet a motive for clinging to public life; till the last of my political friends shall cast me off, all this constitutes my present condition— These are my cares and sorrows—but with them I have numberless blessings for which I cease not to be grateful to the author of all good, and I have the cheering hope of a better world beyond the grave. The late Session of Congress has been painful to me beyond all former experience by the demonstration which it has given of degenerating institutions. Parties are falling into profligate factions— I have seen this before; but the worst symptom now is the change in the manners of the People— The continuance of the present Administration, will if accomplished open wide, all the flood-gates of Corruption— Will a change produce reform? Pause and ponder! Slavery—the Indians— The public Lands— The collection and disbursement of public monies— The Tariff, and foreign Affairs— What is to become of them?

I rose with a dull headache, and was unwell all the morning. I went however to the Presbyterian Church where after waiting some time for the preacher Mr M’Lellan informed the congregation that Mr Wood was absent from the City, but had told him he would engage a person, Dr Chapin, President of the Columbia College to supply the pulpit— It was past 11. and Dr Chapin did not appear—after waiting 5 minutes longer I left the Church, and went to the Methodist foundery chapel where the pews were all as crowded as they could hold, with decent respectable well dressed people men, women and children, not one of whom I personally knew— They politely gave me a chair at the corner of the aisle at the left hand of the pews fronting the pulpit. There was not a spare seat in the pews. There were two Ministers in the pulpit—one of them Mr Thornton, preached from Isaiah 55.6. “Seek ye the Lord, while he may be found, call ye upon him while he is near”— He said he had been greatly perplexed this morning to fix upon a text from which he should discourse this day. That he had at home at least five hundred sketches for Sermons which he had prepared, and one hundred and fifty of which he had never preached any where, he could not find among them one which suited him for this day. But he had often of late thought of giving notice a week before hand, that he would on the next Sabbath address a discourse especially to the young. Instead of which he would perform that duty now— And he particularly asked the attention of the younger portion of his hearers to what he was about to say.— But it did not appear afterwards, why he had asked the special attention of the young.— He subsequently addressed separately and in succession the old and the middle aged as well as the young and his exhortations to them to seek the Lord while he may be found, and to call upon him while he is near, were equally urgent, appropriate and pathetic— Mr Thornton is not very eloquent, but he drew from me many tears— But his definition of seeking and calling upon the Lord was “Religion”—the Species defined by the Genus— Religion! what Religion— The inherent defect of all calvinistic preaching is practical application. Oliver Cromwell said, when they thought he was seeking the Lord he was only seeking a cork screw— The duties of Man to God, are worship, reverence, gratitude, submission and resignation— All in sentiment—prayer and praise in action; which the vilest, as well as the worthiest can and do perform.— I believe the only acceptable obedience to God conists in Justice, charity and mercy to man— After dinner at 5. I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the 6th. Sunday after Trinity and preached from Jeremiah 31.34. [“]And they shall teach no more every man his neighbour, and every man his brother, saying Know the Lord: for they shall all know me, from the least of them, unto the greatest of them, saith the Lord: for I will forgive their iniquity, and I will remember their sin no more:” We all spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s. I walked down there, and Mrs Smith returned with us.

Our coachman Thomas Dumphy was taken suddenly ill and confined to his bed. Mr Vattemare was here this morning, and proposes now to go to Baltimore, Philadelphia, New-York and Boston, before proceeding upon his Southern tour— He said he had obtained upwards of a thousand volumes here to take with him to France for various public institutions there and for which equivalents will be given in exchange— His design embraces medals, coins, natural curiosities, and Newspapers, of which he has already collected upwards of a thousand. He urged me again to write a dedication to the people of the United States for his American Album; but I told him this was a species of composition which every man could write better for himself than for another; and if he would write his dedication in French, I would with pleasure translate it for him into English— He said he would wait then till he should see me at Boston. I received from the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives the papers relating to the claim of Ebenezer Lobdell, and took them to the third Auditor of the Treasury Peter Hagner— At the door of the Navy Department I met Mr Frye; and Mr Moody the husband of Mrs Adelaide Hellen’s daughter Adele— I called in at the Office of the Secretary of the Navy, and had some conversation with him respecting the wretchedly dilapidated Navy Pension fund— He had seen the Resolutions which I offered to the House on this subject, and which they refused to receive. He complained that they had equally disregarded his own reports and even a special message of the President recommending an appropriation of 50000 dollars to pay the Pensions due on the first of this Month. I told Mr Paulding that I doubted the authority of the Department, to sell at a discount State bonds, purchased at or over par.— He said he had been forced to do it, or to stop the payment of the Pensions which would have excited a great clamour— I said that would have compelled Congress to provide for the payments— I told him further that it was my purpose to resume the subject at the ensuing Session of Congress— Mr Hagner gave me an Order, from the Secretary of War upon the Secretary of the Treasury, for 1075 dollars 39 cents as Attorney of Ebenezer Lobdell— I called on the Secretary of War, and condoled with him on the loss of the appropriation for magnetic and meteorological observations— He said there was a good Article on the subject in the English Quarterly Review for June— I took his order to the Secretary of the Treasury, who said he would send me to-morrow morning a draft on the Receiver general at Boston. I condoled with him on the loss of the Revenue Bill.— These gentlemen all have the appearance of being ill at ease— Mrs Stewart was here this evening; and Mr Hawley who is going to Piney point, and urged us much to go there also—

Mr Frye brought me this morning a statement of his account as my agent and attorney for the transaction of my private business in this City from May 1835 to this time with all the vouchers— The account is exact and minute leaving a balance of 622.47. in his hands to provide for outstanding charges, and liabilities— I find no unnecessary charge—constant vigilance and discretion— Everything that constitute an intelligent agent; and a result by which the income from the Columbian Mills—the dwelling house next my own abode; the dwelling house in the Pennsylvania avenue and the dwelling house next to Captain Carbery barely pay their own expenses— In my own hands they would have fared worse— Mr Pope came and took leave— He departs to-morrow morning with Mr Underwood for Kentucky— I called at Mr Force’s and Mr Fendall’s and returned books long since borrowed of them— At the Office of the National Intelligencer where I saw Mr Gales— He promised to send for the back file of my Intelligencer and have them bound— He spoke of the desperate condition of the Bank of the U.S. and of the ominous rumours against Nicholas Biddle, now he said, known to be fals but leaving suspicions of the darkest character afloat, and a fall of the stock from 70 to 63 per cent in one day. At the Bank of Washington, where I could not draw my deposit but by a sacrifice of 2 1/2 per cent. At the Clerk Office of the House of Representatives where I left directions to have forwarded to me the remaining sheets of the House Journal yet to be printed, and the returns of Commerce and Navigation to Septr. 1839. Mr Burch was much perplexed what to do with the papers of the case of Lieutt. Hooe’s Court Martial.— Their proceedings were referred to the Committee on the Judiciary to report the existing Law, and what shall be done— On the last day of the Session Sergeant chairman of the judiciary Committee sent to the clerk’s table under a general order a Resolution that the Committee be discharged from the further consideration of the subject, and a minority report signed by Green B. Samuel of Virginia, Isaac E. Crary of Michigan, and Hopkins L. Turney of Tennessee, expressly stating their full conviction after examination that by the existing Law, the testimony of coloured persons must be received—and with the report a Resolution that the papers be recommitted with instructions to report an amendatory Law either prohibiting the employment of coloured persons in the navy, or rendering them incompetent to bear testimony— Burch was doubtful how those papers should be entered on the Journal, and wrote to Sergeant for advice— He received Sergeant’s answer this morning and read it to me. He says he was told by a member of the Committee, he believes correctly that there was a motion to reconsider.— He therefore declines advising; and Garland Burch said he must write to Mr Garland the Clerk. I desired him to ask a copy of the papers for me; and to demand that they be entered on the Journal. Mrs Thornton, Mrs Talbot and Mary E. E. Cutts were here this Evening.
